messageBody:
I'm wrapping my dialog in an ConfirmationMessageDialog , providing the show method I need.

In this example I made the choice for this project to have a null parentComponent ,"Confirmation" as title and OK_CANCEL as options of the OptionPane.
public class ConfirmationMessageDialog {
/** shows the confirmationMessageDialog
* @param message the message to display in the dialog
* @return an integer indicating if the user clicked "ok" or "cancel".
*/
public int show(String message) {
return JOptionPane.showConfirmDialog(null,message,"Confirmation",JOptionPane.OK_CANCEL_OPTION,JOptionPane.QUESTION_MESSAGE);
}
}

An instance of this class is kept at a central location, class that is a singleton . (some kind of ServiceLocator)
In my Case it's called the Maincontroller.
Initialy the confirmationMessageDialog is filled in but there is a setter and getter.
public class MainController {
private ConfirmationMessageDialog confirmationMessageDialog = new ConfirmationMessageDialog();
private static MainController instance;
public static MainController getInstance() {
if (instance == null){
instance = new MainController();
}
return instance;
}
public ConfirmationMessageDialog getConfirmationMessageDialog() {
return confirmationMessageDialog;
}
public void setConfirmationMessageDialog(ConfirmationMessageDialog confirmationMessageDialog) {
this.confirmationMessageDialog = confirmationMessageDialog;
}
}

In the code, when a confirmation is needed :
int answer = MainController.getInstance().getConfirmationMessageDialog("Are you sure");

In the test of code where this is used, I subclass my ConfirmationMessageDialog and override the show method, returning what I want.
Usually as an innerclass of my testclass, making it easy to manipulate.

public class TestsomeClass{

int returnedConfirmation ;
ConfirmationMessageDialog savedConfirmationMessageDialog = MainController.getInstance().getConfirmationMessageDialog();

protected void setUp(){
// setup my own
MainController.getInstance().setConfirmationMessageDialog(new TestConfirmationMessageDialog());
}
protected void tearDown() {
// reset the real one
MainController.getInstance().setConfirmationMessageDialog(savedConfirmationMessageDialog );
}

public void testSomeMethodWithAConfirmation(){
returnedConfirmation = JOptionPane.CANCEL_OPTION ;
testedClass.someMethodWithAConfirmation();
//test what should happen if user cancelled
returnedConfirmation = JOptionPane.OK_OPTION;
testedClass.someMethodWithAConfirmation();
//test what should happen if user confirmed
}

class TestConfirmationMessageDialog extends ConfirmationMessageDialog {
public int show(String message) {
return returnedConfirmation ;
}
}
}

You can even keep the passed message (showedMessage) and test on it.

This smells a bit as mock testing.
It can be written cleaner with an interface , so that you don't have to subclass but implement instead.

hope this helps,
